title: Britain's athletes fall short of World Champs medal target after relay mix-up
text:

The golden smiles of Katarina Johnson-Thompson and Dina Asher-Smith were replaced by frowns in the British team after a relay blunder left them two medals short of their target, writes Alex Spink in Doha .

A botched changeover between Toby Harries and Rabah Yousif in the men’s 4 x 400m relay ended with the baton on the floor and Britain with five medals - their lowest tally at a World Championships since 2005, when they won only three.

Team boss Neil Black said: “There’s a lot to feel really, really good and positive about. But the reality is the medal tally is not that which we would have wanted and expected.

(Image: PA)

(Image: PA)

“It could be better, it should be better. We’ll obviously be talking with UK Sport with whom we have a really positive relationship about what are we going to do about it. How do we convert the nearlies into medals.”

The Brits thought they had some consolation when the women’s 4 x 4 quartet were upgraded to bronze after Jamaica were disqualified. But 45 minutes later the Jamaicans won their appeal and got the medal back.

The curtain came down on the championships with world athletics supremo Seb Coe admitting it was inevitable the best performances would be “permanently” questioned.

(Image: PA)

(Image: PA)

Coe claimed athletics is in “really good shape” after a champs that “on athlete performance, is the best we have ever had”.

There were indeed world records (women’s 400m hurdles and mixed 4 x 400m relay) and a string of championship bests.

But there was also the Salazar doping scandal bombshell which went off just before two athletes from his coaching group - Sifan Hassan and Donavan Brazier - won gold medals.

(Image: Sportsfile via Getty)

After Hassan’s runaway 1500m triumph on Saturday night British rival Laura Muir said: “Given the news of the past few days, there is a cloud. There’s no avoiding that.”

Coe admitted: "Sadly it is the world we live in. it is inevitable that outstanding performances, given the broader nature of trust, are permanently questioned.

“I’m sure that when I was breaking three world records in 41 days back in 1979, there were people looking slightly askance at what I did.”
